body: Saying he was concerned that increases in reported crime in three Bronx precincts were not being addressed, Police Commissioner Bernard B. Kerik has replaced the precincts' commanders. Although reported crime is down citywide, Mr. Kerik said, the Bronx precincts have shown troubling increases, and he said the commanders there had failed to put
title: 3 Police Commanders in Bronx Are Replaced as Crime Rises

body: LIKE many young actors new to New York, Jeannie Dalton got a place in Brooklyn, took a day job in Midtown Manhattan and started going to auditions. There was only one problem. The commute to Kensington, a Brooklyn neighborhood just past Park Slope, took an hour each way. By the time she got home to the two-bedroom apartment she shared first with a
title: Habitats/43rd Street and Eighth Avenue; An Actor Moves Closer To Day Job and Auditions

body: To the Editor: A public service advertising campaign should be started to encourage people who live in the suburbs to use public transportation to get in and out of the city. Having fewer cars in the city would improve the quality of life and would expose suburbanites to the social benefits of not using a car. MICHAEL P. GAUGHAN Kensington,
title: Can't Find a Parking Spot? Aww.

body: Andrene Francis, 38, had never turned on a computer, let alone used a mouse before. She fumbled. She shook. She was embarrassed in front of other parents who appeared to know the difference between left and right clicking. But Ms. Francis, a home health care aide who runs a day care center from her home in Kensington, a working-class immigrant
title: To Help Children, Computer Lessons for Parents

But by the time the conductor says ''15th Street, Prospect Park,'' the train has arrived at one of northern Brooklyn's leafier neighborhoods, Windsor
title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Windsor Terrace; A Quiet, Accessible Corner of Brooklyn

body: When Frank Perri opened Buzz-A-Rama 500 in 1965, slot car racing was all the rage in New York City. With 45 other model race car businesses in town, any kid could pretend to be Al Unser or Mario Andretti. Now, 35 years later, Mr. Perri said, his slot car establishment is the only one that has survived. And while slot car aerodynamic technology has
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BENSONHURST; 35 Years Later, Mr. Slot Car Remains in the Driver's Seat

body: A GREAT urban myth is that cabdrivers know the best places to eat. Well, guess what: It's no myth, at least when it comes to northern Indian and Pakistani cabby hangouts, where I've had some very exciting meals in the last few weeks. The needs of the on-duty cabby are few: Food must be ready fast, it must be cheap and it must be available around
title: $25 and Under; Driver, Follow That Cab (for Some Fine Indian Fare)

body: If you are dying for a good steak, and you are thinking about Denny's Steak Pub in Kensington, Brooklyn, you might as well come in a hearse. ''We got your clams and scampi, scungilli, veal,'' Tom DeRosa says. ''My chili's good, but we don't got no steak.'' Mr. DeRosa, 55, is the chef de cuisine, whose resume includes Joe's Bar on Avenue U in
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BENDING ELBOWS; A Steak Pub Missing a Central Ingredient: Steak

body: Three young men were fatally shot yesterday in unrelated homicides in New York, the police said. In the first killing, at 2:30 p.m., Carl Briggs, 24, was shot once in the head outside 558 Parkside Avenue in Kensington, Brooklyn. Mr. Briggs was declared dead on arrival at Kings County Hospital Center, said Detective John Giammarino, a police
title: 3 Men Are Fatally Shot Within 8 Hours

title: The Big City; Knowing What's Best For Cabbies

body: After decades of false starts and a near-demolition, a landmarked boathouse in Prospect Park will become home to the National Audubon Society's first-ever urban center. In an agreement signed Wednesday between the society and the Prospect Park Alliance, the building will be restored and reopened to provide programs and classes on nature and
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: PROSPECT PARK; Bird Lovers Will Find a Home in a Beaux-Arts Boathouse

body: A 74-year-old man was shot to death in his Brooklyn home Saturday night by his mentally disturbed son, who was then arrested, the authorities said yesterday. The victim, Solomon Fried, was found dead of a gunshot to the head at his home on Ocean Parkway in Kensington at 9:30 p.m. Saturday, said Officer Cheryl Cox. Mr. Fried's son, Daniel Fried, 42,
title: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK; Son Charged in Slaying Of a Brooklyn Man
